image.altText: Global tax evasion report 2023

items.synopsis: Australians hold more than one-third of a trillion dollars in known tax havens and profit-shifting by multinational firms deprives Treasury of almost $11 billion a year, finds a new international report.

title.children: The cash to fix the climate crisis and cost-of-living pressures is there if tax evasion is stopped

image.altText: The outside of the NAAJA building in Darwin.

items.synopsis: The former chief executive of the North Australian Aboriginal Justice Agency, Priscilla Atkins, is suing the organisation over her termination in February.

title.children: Former Aboriginal justice agency boss takes stand in wrongful dismissal trial

image.altText: Troops stand scattered alone a dirt road.

items.synopsis: The Israeli military says 222 people are being held captive in Gaza, adding that Israeli ground forces also conducted limited raids into Gaza overnight. Follow live.

title.children: Israel revises hostage number, saying Hamas is holding 222 captives in Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: At least 5,087 Palestinians in Gaza have been killed since the war began, acording to new figures released by Gaza health officials. Among the dead are 2,055 children, 1,119 women and 217 elderly people, the Hamas-run Gaza health ministry says. Before the latest update, the death toll as stated by Gaza officials stood at 4,651. The ministry also says 15,274 people have been wounded, up from 14,245 yesterday. In Israel, the latest casualty figures show about 1,400 people have been killed — most during Hamas's initial attack on October 7 — and 4,932 have been wounded, the UN has reported, citing Israeli official sources.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Death toll in Gaza passes 5,000, local health authorities say

children.content: have been killed since the war began, acording to new figures released by Gaza health officials.

people have been killed — most during Hamas's initial attack on October 7 — and 4,932 have been wounded, the UN has reported, citing Israeli official sources.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A third convoy of aid trucks has entered Gaza through the Rafah crossing from Egypt, Reuters reports. The news agency cited an aid worker and two security sources. The Associated Press also reports that a "small aid shipment" had been allowed in. Here's a map showing the Rafah crossing, the only way into Gaza that is not controlled by Israel. On Saturday, 20 trucks entered Gaza in the first aid shipment into the territory since Israel imposed a complete siege at the start of the war. Israel allowed a second convoy of 15 trucks into Gaza on Sunday .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A third convoy of aid trucks crosses into Gaza: Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli military says it has confirmed that 222 people are being held as captives in Gaza. Chief military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari confirmed the number in a televised briefing. Israeli ground forces also conducted limited raids into Gaza overnight to fight gunmen, Hagari said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel conducts limited ground raids in Gaza, puts hostage number at 222

image.altText: Gordon Bradbery

items.synopsis: Lord Mayor Gordon Bradbery AM says he does not support Hamas or the terrorist activities, but has defended the speech Jewish groups have called "reprehensible and irresponsible" by saying the attack didn't happen in a vacuum.

title.children: Local mayor's speech saying 'I know why Hamas did what they did' condemned by Jewish groups

image.altText: Road closed sign on the side of road with crashed truck and car behind it in the bush

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police have confirmed a man and woman, both aged 34, and four girls aged nine, six, four, and two were killed in the crash near Pine Creek last month.

title.children: Police confirm ages of family killed in Pine Creek crash, including four children

image.altText: A close up of a smiling woman.

items.synopsis: A University of Sydney student is among an estimated one million Palestinians displaced by the war in Gaza.

title.children: Asmaa was visiting family when war erupted in Gaza. Now she can't get out

image.altText: Brighton Secondary College Principal Richard Minack has a neutral expression as he stand outside a building

items.synopsis: Brighton Secondary College principal Richard Minack resigns, a month after the Federal Court found Jewish students suffered at school under his watch.

title.children: Melbourne principal resigns after Federal Court finds Jewish students were subject to bullying

image.altText: A man walking into a court surrounded by a media pack

items.synopsis: A judge says Michael John Kable, 63, "was subject to extreme provocation as a casual teacher" prior to the assault at Maitland Grossman High School, and the offence was "out of character".

title.children: Judge overturns high school teacher's conviction for punching student in classroom brawl

image.altText: A composite image of muddy flooded machinery, a large sinkhole, and a metal pipe with gas coming out of it.

items.synopsis: Snowy Hydro's tunnelling machine caused a sinkhole and spent months barely moving, then the troubled project's tunnel began filling with gas.

title.children: 'You've screwed up, haven't you?': The $2 billion mistake behind Snowy 2.0

image.altText: ASX boards showing red down arrows

items.synopsis: The Australian share market has entered a "technical correction", while war, economic uncertainty and higher interest rates create the perfect storm, writes David Taylor.

title.children: ​​​​​​​The share market has just 'corrected', so how much of a worry is that?

image.altText: Black and white image of Rock Hudson, he is wearing a dark coloured shirt. He is looking to the right in the picture.

items.synopsis: Rock Hudson's chiselled masculinity and effortless charm made him a much sought-after romantic lead in a string of 1950s and 1960s movie classics. What the world didn't know was that this matinee idol was gay.

title.children: 'He was the Tom Cruise of his day': An All-American idol, Rock Hudson's secret double life laid bare in documentary

image.altText: Timothy Courtney wearing glasses and a blue button up shirt

items.synopsis: Timothy Courtney says the abuse started when he was in year 3 at Beaumaris Primary School. He tells a state inquiry he hopes sharing his story will help to reduce the stigma felt by other survivors.

title.children: Inquiry begins into horrors at Victorian state-run primary schools

image.altText: A man sits on his exercise bike in his garage

items.synopsis: The Gold Coast man is recovering at home with a new outlook, a month after medical complications during a Balinese holiday prompted a massive outpouring of support — and an emergency evacuation.

title.children: 'I'm grateful for everything': Surf coach Mark Richardson nearly died in a Bali hospital but now has new lease on life

image.altText: group of people walking down jetty at Moreton Bay

items.synopsis: Moreton Bay has 94 suburbs, takes nearly an hour to traverse and is expecting 240 new residents a week for the next 25 years. But those who live here fear they're not prepared to cope with the impending population explosion.

title.children: This council is expecting 240 new residents a week for the next 25 years — and that has some concerned

image.altText: Taylor Swift celebrates with Brittany Mahomes

items.synopsis: Taylor Swift continues to dominate coverage as she supports Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs — here's what the melding of two of America's biggest pop culture phenomena mean for both Swifties and the NFL.

title.children: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce are a phenomenon that is not going away — here's what it means for the NFL

image.altText: Meryl Streep and Don Gummer at the 90th Acadmey Awards in 2018.

items.synopsis: Another stalwart Hollywood couple reveal they have been separated for several years.

title.children: Meryl Streep confirms she's been separated from husband for six years

image.altText: A man wearing a rainbow lanyard sits at a desk, glancing down.

items.synopsis: A "Hotties List" of graduate women in the Infrastructure Department was reportedly circulated by male graduates, according to a complaint by one employee.

title.children: Junior women reportedly ranked in 'Hotties List' circulated by Infrastructure Department staff

image.altText: A large fire burns on top of trees in a forrest

items.synopsis: Residents at Cypress Gardens, Millmerran Downs and Tara are being warned to leave immediately due to fast-moving bushfires.

title.children: Firefighters warn they are struggling to control fast-moving fires in southern Queensland

image.altText: A red R-F-S fire truck in front of burning trees.

items.synopsis: Residents around Glens Creek Road and Frickers Road at Nymboida are being advised to prepare now after a bushfire burning in the area returned to the emergency warning level.

title.children: NSW North Coast community on alert after second day of bushfire warnings

image.altText: A man carries a young girl wearing pink pyjamas with a worried and urgent expression on his face

items.synopsis: If we do not understand the pain and misery on both sides of this war, then we cannot begin to think of how to help stop the never-ending cycle of pain and misery in Gaza, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Imagine cutting Canberra in half and putting the population of Brisbane into it before dropping 6,000 bombs

image.altText: photo of sign to new Bendigo Courthouse on a sunny day

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest into the death of a 17-year-old Aboriginal girl in Central Victoria is investigating the adequacy and responsiveness of the state's child protection services.

title.children: 'I do not feel supported by you': Inquest hears Aboriginal teen's plea to child protection ahead of tragic suicide

image.altText: A man with a bald head and beard wears a black jacket and sits against a black background

items.synopsis: As a child Scott Wynands was "very hot tempered" and inquisitive — once putting a sandwich in a VHS player — but being diagnosed with ADHD at 43 helped him make sense of his life's trajectory.

title.children: Scott 'lost lots of jobs' because of ADHD. He wants others to know what the condition is like

image.altText: Sharon Graham and Bruce Saunders smile together with their heads close together.

items.synopsis: Secret conversations captured on hidden police recording devices inside the home of Sharon Graham have been played to a jury.

title.children: Hidden police recordings aired in trial of woman whose ex-partner was fed through woodchipper

image.altText: A smiling Britney Spears holding two MTV award statues, wearing a black, high-necked top

items.synopsis: It's not publicly available yet, but the tell-all book has already been the subject of a flurry of stories about the star's hidden personal life and reignited conversations about the dark side of naughties pop culture.

title.children: 'It's given me closure': Britney Spears's memoir charts the colourful life of one of pop music's best-loved performers

image.altText: Australian Diamonds wig attack Liz Watson collides with New Zealand Silver Ferns opponents during the Constellation Cup.

items.synopsis: Australia secures its 11th Constellation Cup crown on points aggregate despite losing the final two Tests of the series in New Zealand.

title.children: Diamonds win Constellation Cup despite losing final Test

image.altText: The steps and brown front door of a courthouse

items.synopsis: The 45-year-old Broome man left his partner with second degree-burns following the violent attack, described by the sentencing judge as "totally unacceptable".

title.children: WA man jailed for five years after pouring boiling soup over partner

image.altText: lights from phytoplankton in the water

items.synopsis: Passers-by describe it as stepping into a "dream world" but experts say the bright blue and green lights from bioluminescent algae are a marker for the warming planet.

title.children: Grant saw a 'surreal' blue light in the water. Experts say it's a sign of climate change

image.altText: A young man smiles at the camera wearing a vintage Parramatta Eels jumper.

items.synopsis: In 1996, exactly 27 years today, 17-year-old Michael Hegedus was shot in the chest and stomach in what police say was a botched service station robbery. A reward for information is being offered by police.

title.children: Billy was 17 when he was killed in a robbery gone wrong. A $1m reward hopes to solve the cold case

image.altText: A person wearing a bike helmet standing at an empty bank counter

items.synopsis: Kym Parsons, who is accused of carrying out 10 bank robberies while armed with a rifle in South Australia, has been granted home detention bail.

title.children: Alleged 'bicycle bandit' robbed banks while battling cancer, SA court hears

image.altText: Dwayne Johnstone without shirt, wearing black hat, sunglasses on hat and chains around neck.

items.synopsis: A jury listens to a correctional officer describe the moment he discharged his firearm during an inmate's attempted escape in northern NSW.

title.children: 'You got me, chief': Video of correctional officer's police interview played during murder trial
